data.bulletinTitle: FN70458 - Certain NCS 5500 Products Are Not Supported With Software Releases Earlier Than Cisco IOS XR 6.5.2/6.6.1 or Without the Mandatory SMU - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Certain Network Convergence System (NCS) 5500 products, as mentioned in the Products Affected section, are not compatible with Cisco IOS¿¿ XR Software Releases earlier than 6.5.2/6.6.1 or without the mandatory Software Maintenance Upgrade (SMU). These routers/line cards might fail to boot without the required software release version or mandatory SMU.
data.background: A new hardware version for the products will be introduced to address the End of Life (EoL) of an existing memory component. This version will be supported by Cisco IOS XR Software Release 6.5.2, 6.6.1, or later only.For software releases earlier than 6.5.2/6.6.1, a mandatory reload SMU needs to be installed.
data.problemSymptoms: This error log will be observed when the NCS 5500 product boots with a non-compatible Cisco IOS XR Software Release or without the mandatory SMU.fia_driver[<IGNORE>]: %FABRIC-FIA_DRVR-3-ASIC_INIT_FAILURE : [<IGNORE>] : Asic Initialization failed due to:soc reset init failed, device <slice> with error 0xfffffffffffffffc(Invalid parameter)
data.workaround: The NCS 5500 products, which run on Cisco IOS XR Software Releases earlier than 6.5.2/6.6.1, require one of these options in order to support the new hardware version.Option 1. Install the SMUsCisco IOS XR Software ReleaseRequired SMU File Names6.3.15ncs5500-6.3.15.CSCvn11904.tar6.3.2ncs5500-6.3.2.CSCvn11904.tar6.3.3ncs5500-6.3.3.CSCvn11904.tar6.2.3To be posted6.1.3To be posted6.1.4To be posted Option 2. UpgradeCisco IOS XR software can be migrated to one of the latest Cisco IOS XR Software Releases: 6.5.2, 6.6.1, or later. These releases do not require any of the SMUs.Open the NCS 5500 Software Download Page for the latest software releases.
data.caveat: Manual verification of software release or SMU is required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70464 - ASR900 and ASR920 Products Do Not Support a Software Version Rollback from Cisco IOS XE  Versions 17.1.1, 16.6.7, 16.9.4, 16.12.1, 3.18.7SP and Later to Previous Versions - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Cisco ASR 900 Series Aggregation Services Routers (ASR 900) and ASR 920 routers (as mentioned in the Products Affected section) do not support a software version rollback (see the Workaround/Solution section for more details) from Cisco IOS¿¿ XE Versions 17.1.1, 16.6.7, 16.9.4, 16.12.1, 3.18.7SP and later to previous versions. If a roll back is attempted by customers, the secure boot logic will detect tampering and set the router into a continuous boot loop.
data.background: See the Cisco Security Advisory Secure Boot Hardware Tampering Vulnerability (CVE-2019-1649).Cisco IOS XE Versions 17.1.1, 16.6.7, 16.9.4, 16.12.1, 3.18.7SP and later were released to address this vulnerability for the ASR 900/920 products. After you upgrade to any version which addresses this security vulnerability, roll back to a previous version where vulnerability is exposed is not allowed.
data.problemSymptoms: The impacted router will go into a continuous boot loop when a roll back is done from the Cisco IOS XE versions listed in the Problem Description section to previous versions. See the Workaround/Solution section for more details.These logs will be displayed during bootup:FPGA UPGRADE Done: System going for rebootSystem Bootstrap, Version 15.6(10r)S, RELEASE SOFTWARE (fc1)Technical Support: http://www.cisco.com/techsupportCopyright (c) 2016 by cisco Systems, Inc.Compiled Thu 24-Mar-16 15:38 by alnguyenBoot ROM1Last reset cause: PowerOnUEA platform with 3670016 Kbytes of main memory
data.workaround: See this Software Release Migration Matrix for more details on supported/not supported migration paths.Note: For customers who plan to migrate to the latest Cisco IOS XE versions (as mentioned in the Problem Description section), a roll back to a previous version is not supported post upgrade.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70467 - ASA Software - AnyConnect Connections Might Fail With TCP Connection Limit Exceeded Error - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Some versions of Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) software might cause AnyConnect sessions to fail after a low number of users are connected.
data.background: The ASA software allows up to six HTTP management sessions on the security appliance. Due to a software issue, AnyConnect sessions might be considered as additional HTTP management sessions. If the total number of HTTP management and AnyConnect sessions equals the six session limit, additional AnyConnect sessions might fail.The issue might occur with this ASA configuration:SSL VPN configurationWith an interface with both http and webvpn configuration enabledhttp server enablehttp <ip> <mask> <i/f nameif>webvpn  enable <i/f nameif>
data.problemSymptoms: AnyConnect sessions fail after a low number of users are connected. The syslog files will contain a "TCP connection limit exceeded" error similar to the example shown below.%ASA-7-710004: TCP connection limit exceeded from <x.x.x.x>/<port> to <nameif>:y.y.y.y/443 (current connections/connection limit = 6/6)
data.workaround: Cisco recommends that you upgrade to one of these ASA software versions:9.8(4.8) or later9.10(1.26) or later9.12(2.13) or later9.12(3.1) or laterUpdated ASA software versions that address this issue are available from the Software Download page for customers with a valid service contract.
data.caveat: Additonal notes

data.bulletinTitle: FN70476 - ASA5508 and ASA5516 Security Appliances Might Fail After 18 Months or Longer Due to a Damaged Component - Hardware Upgrade Required
data.problemDescription: The Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) ASA5508 and ASA5516 might fail in operation, after 18 months or longer, due to a damaged component.
data.background: Due to a manufacturing process issue, some ASA5508 and ASA5516 security appliances might have a damaged resistor component. The affected units were manufactured between 2017-05-18 and 2017-08-25.Security appliances with a damaged resistor will function normally on installation and product failures are expected to increase over time beginning after the unit has been in operation for approximately 18 months. Once the security appliance has failed the unit will no longer function, will not boot, and is not recoverable.
data.problemSymptoms: The security appliance no longer functions and the system fails to boot. There will be no output from the console port.In addition, the LED status indicators on the security appliance illuminate as follows:Power LED is greenStatus LED is amber and blinking
data.workaround: Cisco recommends proactive replacement for affected ASA5508 and ASA5516 security appliances. There is no workaround for this issue.Customers should request replacements for affected product(s) with the order form provided in the Upgrade Program section of this field notice.For customers that request replacements, note that the license activation key is tied to the ASA chassis serial number. Contact the Cisco Licensing Team in order to have your current license transferred to the replacement chassis serial number. The Cisco Licensing Team will ask for the Product Authorization Key reference number and current serial number. Additional information in regards to ASA licensing can be referenced in the Cisco ASA Series General Operations CLI Configuration Guide, 9.6.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70479 - Out-Of-The-Box AP Fails to Join Controller or Joins with Single Radio Due to Country Mismatch - Replace on Failure
data.problemDescription: A newly installed Access Point (AP) fails to join its controller or it joins the controller, but is only able to bring up one radio due to a manufacturing mismatch between the AP's domain and the radio's domain.On a Mobility Express (ME) AP, the 2.4GHz radio will come up in Day 0 mode; however, after you configure the correct country code, the internal AP might fail to rejoin or might bring up only one radio.
data.background: In the manufacturing process, the radios for some APs were set for regulatory domains which do not match the Product ID (PID).
data.problemSymptoms: Errors similar to these are seen in an AireOS Wireless LAN Controller's (WLC's) msglog:*spamApTask0: Jul 22 18:00:21.474: %LWAPP-3-RD_ERR8: [PA]spam_lrad.c:12332 Country code (CN) not configured for AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx*spamApTask5: Jul 22 18:00:19.549: %CAPWAP-3-POST_DECODE_ERR: [PA]capwap_ac_sm.c:6688 Post decode processing failed for Config status from AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx*spamApTask0: Jul 22 18:00:21.474: %LWAPP-3-RD_ERR8: [PA]spam_lrad.c:12332 Country code (CN) not configured for AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx*spamApTask5: Jul 22 18:00:19.549: %CAPWAP-3-DTLS_CLOSED_ERR: [PA]capwap_ac_sm.c:7289 xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx: DTLS connection closed forAP X.X.X.X (5264), Controller: X.X.X.X (5246) Regulatory Domain Mismatch*spamApTask0: Jul 22 18:00:21.474: %LWAPP-3-RD_ERR8: [PA]spam_lrad.c:12332 Country code (CN) not configured for AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx*spamApTask5: Jul 22 18:00:19.549: %LWAPP-3-RD_ERR4: [PA]capwap_ac_sm.c:3467 The system detects an invalid regulatory domain 802.11bg:-A 802.11a:-TZ for AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx*spamApTask0: Jul 22 18:00:21.474: %LWAPP-3-RD_ERR8: [PA]spam_lrad.c:12332 Country code (CN) not configured for AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx*spamApTask5: Jul 22 18:00:19.549: %LOG-3-Q_IND: [PA]spam_lrad.c:12332 Country code (CN) not configured for AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx[...It occurred 2 times.!]*spamApTask0: Jul 22 18:00:21.474: %LWAPP-3-RD_ERR8: [PA]spam_lrad.c:12332 Country code (CN) not configured for AP xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xxErrors similar to these are seen in a 9800 Series Wireless LAN Controller's (WLC's) log:*Jan  7 14:00:06.144: %APMGR_TRACE_MESSAGE-3-EWLC_GEN_ERR: Chassis 1 R0/0: wncd: Error in d4e8.801a.3080 AP will be disconnected. Regulatory domain validation failed during configuration phase. Country code: XX
data.workaround: Use the Wireless LAN Compliance Lookup Tool in order to validate that your country code matches your PID.If you observe the same symptom and have validated that the correct countries are configured on your controller for your APs, but your serial number does not show up in the Serial Number Validation Tool, open a Technical Assistance Center (TAC) Service Request (SR) to conduct further troubleshooting.If you have an affected unit whose serial number is matched in the Serial Number Validation Tool, order a replacement unit with the Upgrade Program form.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70489 - PKI Self-Signed Certificate Expiration in Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE Software - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: Self-signed X.509 PKI certificates (SSC) that were generated on devices that run affected Cisco IOS¿¿ or Cisco IOS XE software releases expire on 2020-01-01 00:00:00 UTC. New self-signed certificates cannot be created on affected devices after 2020-01-01 00:00:00 UTC. Any service that relies on these self-signed certificates to establish or terminate a secure connection might not work after the certificate expires.This issue affects only self-signed certificates that were generated by the Cisco IOS or Cisco IOS XE device and applied to a service on the device. Certificates that were generated by a Certificate Authority (CA), which includes those certificates generated by the Cisco IOS CA feature, are not impacted by this issue.
data.background: Certain features in Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE software rely on digitally signed X.509 certificates for cryptographic identity validation. These certificates can be generated by an external third-party CA or they can be generated on the Cisco IOS or Cisco IOS XE device itself as a self-signed certificate. Affected releases of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE software will always set the self-signed certificate's expiration date to 2020-01-01 00:00:00 UTC. After this date, the certificate expires and is invalid.Services that might rely on a self-signed certificate include:General Features:HTTP Server over TLS (HTTPS) - HTTPS will produce an error in the browser which indicates that the certificate is expired.SSH Server - Users who use X.509 certificates to authenticate the SSH session might fail to authenticate. (This use of X.509 certificates is rare. Username/password authentication and public/private key authentication are not affected.)RESTCONF - RESTCONF connections might fail.Collaboration Features:Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) over TLSCisco Unified Communications Manager Express (CME) with encrypted signaling enabledCisco Unified Survivable Remote Site Telephony (SRST) with encrypted signaling enabledCisco IOS dspfarm resources (Conference, Media Termination Point, or Transcoding) with encrypted signaling enabledSkinny Client Control Protocol (SCCP) Telephony Control Application (STCAPP) ports configured with encrypted signalingMedia Gateway Control Protocol (MGCP) and H.323 call signaling over IP security (IPSec) without a pre-shared keyCisco Unified Communications Gateway Services API in Secure Mode (using HTTPS)Wireless Features:LWAPP/CAPWAP connections between older Cisco IOS access points (manufactured in 2005 or earlier) >FN63942 for more details.
data.problemSymptoms: An attempt to generate a self-signed certificate on an affected Cisco IOS or Cisco IOS XE software release after 2020-01-01 00:00:00 UTC results in this error:  ../cert-c/source/certobj.c(535) : E_VALIDITY : validity period start later than endAny services that rely on the self-signed certificate will no longer function. For example:SIP over TLS calls will not complete.Devices registered to Cisco Unified CME with encrypted signaling enabled will no longer function.Cisco Unified SRST with encrypted signaling enabled will not allow devices to register.Cisco IOS dspfarm resources (Conference, Media Termination Point, or Transcoding) with encrypted signaling enabled will no longer register.STCAPP ports configured with encrypted signaling will no longer register.Calls through a gateway using MGCP or H.323 call signaling over IPSec without a pre-shared key will fail.API calls that use the Cisco Unified Communications Gateway Services API in Secure Mode (using HTTPS) will fail.RESTCONF will fail.HTTPS sessions to manage the device will display a browser warning, which indicates that the certificate has expired.AnyConnect SSL VPN sessions will fail to establish or report an invalid certificate.IPSec connections will fail to establish.
data.workaround: The solution is to upgrade the Cisco IOS or Cisco IOS XE software to a release that includes the fix:Cisco IOS XE Software Release 16.9.1 and laterCisco IOS Software Release.6(3)M7 and later; 15.7(3)M5 and later; or 15.8(3)M3 and laterAfter you upgrade the software, you must regenerate the self-signed certificate and export it to any devices that might require the certificate in their trust-store.Three workarounds are available if an immediate software upgrade is not feasible.Workaround 1Install a certificate from a CA.With this workaround, a certificate request is generated and displayed by Cisco IOS. The administrator then copies the request and submits it to a third-party CA and retrieves the result.Note: Use of a CA to sign certificates is considered to be a security best-practice. This procedure is provided as a workaround in this field notice; however, it is preferable to continue to use the third-party CA-signed certificate after you apply this workaround, rather than to use a self-signed certificate.In order to install a certificate from a third-party CA, complete these steps:Create a Certificate Signing Request (CSR).Router# conf tEnter configuration commands, one per line. End with CNTL/Z.Router(config)# crypto pki trustpoint TESTRouter(ca-trustpoint)# enrollment term pemRouter(ca-trustpoint)# subject-name CN=TESTRouter(ca-trustpoint)# revocation-check noneRouter(ca-trustpoint)# rsakeypair TESTRouter(ca-trustpoint)# exitRouter(config)# crypto pki enroll TEST% Start certificate enrollment ..% The subject name in the certificate will include: CN=TEST% The subject name in the certificate will include: Router.cisco.com% The serial number in the certificate will be: FTX1234A>% Include an IP address in the subject name? [no]: noDisplay Certificate Request to terminal? [yes/no]: yesCertificate Request follows:-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE REQUEST-----A Base64 Certificate is displayed here. Copy it, along with the ---BEGIN and ---END lines.-----END CERTIFICATE REQUEST--------End - This line not part of the certificate request---Submit the CSR to the third-party CA.Note: The procedure to submit the CSR to a third-party CA and retrieve the resulting certificate varies based on the CA that is being used. Consult the documentation for your CA for instructions on how to perform this step.Download the new identity certificate for the router along with the CA certificate.Install the CA certificate on the device.Router# conf tEnter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.Router(config)# crypto pki auth TESTEnter the base 64 encoded CA certificate.End with a blank line or the word "quit" on a line by itself-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----REMOVED-----END CERTIFICATE-----Certificate has the following attributes:   Fingerprint MD5: 79D15A9F C7EB4882 83AC50AC 7B0FC625   Fingerprint SHA1: 0A80CC2C 9C779D20 9071E790 B82421DE B47E9006   % Do you accept this certificate? [yes/no]: yesTrustpoint CA certificate accepted.% Certificate successfully importedInstall the identity certificate on the device.Router(config)# crypto pki import TEST certificateEnter the base 64 encoded certificate.End with a blank line or the word "quit" on a line by itself-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----REMOVED-----END CERTIFICATE-----% Router Certificate successfully importedWorkaround 2Use the local Cisco IOS CA server to generate and sign a new certificate.Note: The local CA server feature is not available on all products.Router# conf tEnter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.Router(config)# ip http serverRouter(config)# crypto pki server IOS-CARouter(cs-server)# grant autoRouter(cs-server)# database level completeRouter(cs-server)# no shut%Some server settings cannot be changed after CA certificate generation.% Please enter a passphrase to protect the private key% or type Return to exitPassword: <password>Re-enter password: <password>% Generating 1024 bit RSA keys, keys will be non-exportable...[OK] (elapsed time was 1 seconds)% Certificate Server enabled.Router# show crypto pki server IOS-CA CertificatesSerial Issued date Expire date Subject Name1 21:31:40 EST Jan 1 2020 21:31:40 EST Dec 31 2022 cn=IOS-CARouter# conf tEnter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.Router(config)# crypto pki trustpoint TESTRouter(ca-trustpoint)# enrollment url http://<local interface ip>:80 # Replace <local interface ip> with the IP address of an interface on the routerRouter(ca-trustpoint)# subject-name CN=TESTRouter(ca-trustpoint)# revocation-check noneRouter(ca-trustpoint)# rsakeypair TESTRouter(ca-trustpoint)# exitRouter# conf tEnter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.Router(config)# crypto pki auth TESTCertificate has the following attributes:Fingerprint MD5: C281D9A0 337659CB D1B03AA6 11BD6E40Fingerprint SHA1: 1779C425 3DCEE86D 2B11C880 D92361D6 8E2B71FF% Do you accept this certificate? [yes/no]: yesTrustpoint CA certificate accepted.Router(config)# crypto pki enroll TEST%% Start certificate enrollment ..% Create a challenge password. data.bulletinTitle: FN70495 - ASR1001-X ROMMON Downgraded to a Version Earlier Than 16.2(1r) or Cisco IOS XE Downgraded to a Version Earlier Than Cisco IOS XE 3.16.2/3.15.2 Will Fail to Boot - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: An ASR1001-X ROM monitor (ROMMON) downgraded to a version earlier than Version 16.2(1r) or Cisco IOS¿¿ XE downgraded to a version earlier than Cisco IOS XE Software Release 3.16.2/3.15.2 will fail to boot. This issue only impacts ASR1001-X routers ordered after 2020-01-31. Products ordered prior to 2020-01-31 are not impacted.
data.background: ASR1001-X routers ordered after 2020-01-31 will ship with a new CPU that requires a new minimum ROMMON version and Cisco IOS XE software release. These routers will not be able to boot with ROMMON versions earlier than Version 16.2(1r) or Cisco IOS XE software releases earlier than Cisco IOS XE Software Release 3.16.2/3.15.2.
data.problemSymptoms: The router will fail to boot and will display this message:R0/0: %BOOT-0-DRV_LOADFAIL: Failed to load driver coretemp ( FATAL: Error inserting coretemp (/lib/modules/2.6.32.59/kernel/drivers/hwmon/coretemp.ko): No such device )
data.workaround: A software upgrade is required. ASR1001-X routers ordered after 2020-01-31 need to upgrade to, at a minimum, these releases:ROMMON Version 16.2(1r)Cisco IOS XE Software Release 3.16.2/3.15.2
data.caveat: Manual verification of version, ROMMON, and order date is required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70496 - Cisco IP Phones Might Fail to Operate Correctly Due to Expired Manufacturer Installed Certificate - Configuration Change Recommended
data.problemDescription: Cisco IP Phones that only contain and utilize the Manufacturer Installed Certificate (MIC) for secure network deployment will fail to operate when the certificate expires. In the event of certificate expiration, an administrator must install a Locally Significant Certificate (LSC) in order to ensure secure device communication and operation.See Configure LSC on Cisco IP Phone with CUCM for more information.
data.background: Phones manufactured prior to 2018 might contain a MIC with a 10-year expiration date that could impact phone functionality in certain secure deployment scenarios. In non-secure deployments, phones that contain expired MICs will continue to operate as normal. Customers that previously configured phones in a secure deployment reported to the Technical Assistance Center (TAC) that phones older than 10 years no longer work. Cisco TAC has analyzed the conditions and provided a resolution.
data.problemSymptoms: Phone failure symptoms vary from the inability to register to Unified Communications Manager (Unified CM) to not completing call media path setup for a placed call.The known scenarios in which a phone will not work properly with an expired MIC are:802.1x authentication at a switching level (RADIUS, Identity Services Engine, and so on)VPN connection that utilizes certificate-based authentication (Adaptive Security Appliance or Cisco IOS¿¿)Secure device registration with Unified CMRestricted access to the phone's webpage via any current browserSecure Survivable Remote Site Telephony (SRST) registration on a voice gateway in the case of a Unified CM failureProblem ImpactThe impact to the customer¿¿¿s network includes loss of voice communications, intermittent call interruptions, or non-deterministic endpoint behavior. Phones previously deployed and configured in a secure manner that use the supported LSC method and also contain an expired MIC will continue to operate normally.
data.workaround: Cisco IP Phones do not support field replacement of the MIC. No hardware replacement is necessary as the LSC method is tested, supported, and adds additional security to the phone and the Unified Communications deployment.If a customer encounters issues related to secure deployment or features on the phones, then the administrator should follow the procedure in Configure LSC on Cisco IP Phone with CUCM in order to install LSCs for secure communication.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70500 - Cisco Identity Services Engine and Network Admission Control Posture Updates and Client Provisioning Resource Downloads Will Fail If Configured with a Perfigo URL - Configuration Change Recommended
data.problemDescription: For all affected versions of Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) and Cisco Network Admission Control (NAC), posture updates and client provisioning resource downloads will fail if they are manually configured with a Perfigo.com domain URL.Posture updates will fail if the Update Feed URL field points to https://www.perfigo.com/ise/posture-update.xml.Client provisioning resource downloads will fail if the Update Feed URL field points to https://www.perfigo.com/ise/provisioning-update.xml.
data.background: On 2020-02-17, posture update files and client provisioning resources hosted on Cisco¿¿¿s Perfigo.com web server will no longer be accessible. Corrective action is only required if the default configuration URL was altered.For ISE Release 2.4 and later, the correct default configuration URLs are:https://www.cisco.com/web/secure/spa/posture-update.xmlhttps://www.cisco.com/web/secure/spa/provisioning-update.xmlFor ISE Release 2.3 and earlier, the correct default configuration URLs are:https://www.cisco.com/web/secure/pmbu/posture-update.xml https://www.cisco.com/web/secure/pmbu/provisioning-update.xml
data.problemSymptoms: If posture updates and client provisioning resource downloads continue to point to the Perfigo URL after the Perfigo web server is taken offline, these error messages will be seen:Posture UpdatesClient Provisioning
data.workaround: Posture UpdatesIn ISE, choose Administration > System > Settings > Posture > Updates. Change the Update Feed URL configuration to https://www.cisco.com/web/secure/spa/posture-update.xml.Client ProvisioningIn ISE, choose Administration > System > Settings > Client Provisioning. Change the Update Feed URL configuration to https://www.cisco.com/web/secure/spa/provisioning-update.xml.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70506 - Authentication Failure Observed on C9200/C9200L Switches When a Stacking Cable, Stack Adapter, or Network Module Is Inserted in the Switch - Hardware Upgrade Available
data.problemDescription: A set of Stack cable, Stack Adapter and the network module as mentioned in affected Product List, manufactured during certain period will fail to authenticate when inserted to a stack port of C9200/C9200L switches causing switch to reload.
data.background: A set of stack cables, stack adapter and network modules, manufactured during certain period of time, were tested with wrong ACT2 programming script. This might cause Stack adapter authentication failure  (ACT2 authentication was missed) in the field. Corrective action has been implemented to fix this issue. As of date Jan-10-2020, the failure is expected to be less than 1%.
data.problemSymptoms: The impacted product when inserted into the stack port will fail to authenticate and may show any of the error messages as below. For Stack Cable Authentication failure*** Stack cable authentication failed for cable inserted on stack port 1 on switch 2 ****** Stack cable authentication failed for cable inserted on stack port 2 on switch 2 ****** Stack cable authentication failed for cable inserted on stack port 1 on switch 1 ****** Stack cable authentication failed for cable inserted on stack port 2 on switch 1 *** For Stack Adapter Authentication failureStack Adapter Auth Fail : SIF_SERDES_CABLE_EASTBOUND *** Stack adapter authentication failed on stack port 1 on switch 1 *** Stack adapter authentication failed on stack port 2 on switch 1 Stack Adapter Auth Fail : SIF_SERDES_CABLE_WESTBOUND For Network Module Authentication failure***Uplink FRU module hardware authentication failed***
data.workaround: There is no workaround to fix this issue. If the issue is observed as mentioned in Problem Symptom section and the Serial Number is listed in Serial Number Verification Tool, please create replacement request using the Umpire Form attached below and flag Failure Code as Field Notice Alert.Please ask customer to return the impacted Stack cable/Stack adapter/Network module to return to Cisco or purge at customer end to avoid any mixing up. If the switch fails with similar symptom but not included in the SN validation link, please analyse further on this issue or contact BE before replacing the switch.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70533 - Fans on Cisco UCS C220 M5 or C125 M5 Servers with RAID Controllers Might Run at Full Speed - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: After you upgrade the Cisco Unified Computing System (UCS) C220 M5 or C125 M5 servers with a RAID controller to UCS Manager 4.1(1a) C Bundle or Integrated Management Controller (IMC) Software Release 4.1(1c), the fans run at maximum speed.
data.background: After you upgrade the Cisco UCS C220 M5 or C125 M5 servers with a RAID controller to UCS Manager 4.1(1a) C Bundle or IMC Software Release 4.1(1c), the thermal threshold drops to zero which causes the fans to run at maximum speed.
data.problemSymptoms: Fans run at maximum speed on Cisco UCS C220 M5 or C125 M5 servers with a RAID controller that runs UCS Manager 4.1(1a) C Bundle or IMC Software Release 4.1(1c).
data.workaround: Upgrade to UCS Manager 4.1(1b) C Bundle or Cisco IMC Software Release 4.1(1d).

data.bulletinTitle: FN70544 - Firepower 1100 Series - Some FPR1120 and FPR1140 Security Appliances Might Be Incorrectly Labeled as FPR1150 - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: The rear panel of some Cisco Firepower 1120 and 1140 security appliances might be incorrectly labeled as a Firepower 1150 security appliance.
data.background: Affected FPR1120 and FPR1140 units shipped from 2019-10-31 through 2020-02-13. Some of these units might incorrectly show the silkscreen labeling of the FPR1150 security appliance on the rear panel.
data.problemSymptoms: Perform a visual inspection of the silkscreen labeling on the rear panel of the FPR1120 or FPR1140 security appliance. The issue affects the areas outlined in these images.The correct silkscreen labeling is shown in this image.The incorrect silkscreen labeling is shown in this image. Note that the SFP ports of the FPR1120 and FPR1140 are limited to 1Gbps per the data sheet specifications.
data.workaround: No action is required for customers with affected units.This is a cosmetic issue only and there is no functional impact to the security appliance. Correct product information can be found on the compliance label located on the bottom surface of the security appliance or from the management CLI.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70549 - ASA5506, ASA5508, and ASA5516 Security Appliances - Some RMA Replacements Might Fail Due to a Rework Process Issue - Hardware Upgrade Available
data.problemDescription: Some Adaptive Security Appliances (ASAs) provided as Return Material Authorization (RMA) replacements might fail in operation due to a rework process error that resulted in the omission of a proactive fix.
data.background: Due to a rework process error, some ASA5506, ASA5508, and ASA5516 security appliances that were provided as RMA replacements might be missing a proactive fix. The affected RMA replacements were shipped from spare depots to customers between April 2018 and July 2019. Manufacturing new units that shipped from spare depots or shipped by direct order fulfillment are not affected by this issue.Affected security appliances will function normally on installation, but product failures are expected to increase over time. After the security appliance has failed, the unit will no longer function, will not boot, and is not recoverable.
data.problemSymptoms: The security appliance no longer functions and the system fails to boot. There will be no output from the console port.In addition, the LED status indicators on the security appliance illuminate as follows:Power LED is green.Status LED is amber and blinking.
data.workaround: Cisco recommends replacement of affected ASA security appliances. There is no workaround for this issue.Customers should request replacements for affected products with the order form provided in the Upgrade Program section of this field notice.For customers who request replacements, note that the license activation key is tied to the ASA chassis serial number. Contact the Cisco Licensing Team in order to have your current license transferred to the replacement chassis serial number. The Cisco Licensing Team will ask for the Product Authorization Key reference number and current serial number. For more information about ASA licensing, see Cisco ASA Series General Operations CLI Configuration Guide, 9.6.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70564 - New Hardware Revision to Cisco vEdge 100m and Cisco vEdge 100b Routers Requires SD-WAN Software Upgrade - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Beginning in June 2020, newly manufactured Cisco vEdge 100b and Cisco vEdge 100m routers will no longer support Cisco Software Defined WAN (SD-WAN) software releases prior to 18.4.4.
data.background: Cisco vEdge 100b and vEdge 100m routers contain non-volatile NAND storage that conforms to the eMMC 4.5 standard (embedded multi-media controller). eMMC 4.5 is now obsolete and has been replaced by the eMMC 5.0 standard. Because the eMMC 4.5 components in the affected vEdge routers are now obsolete and are no longer available from suppliers, Cisco has changed production of vEdge 100b and vEdge 100m routers to use eMMC 5.0 compliant components. These new eMMC 5.0 NAND storage components require software changes in the Cisco SD-WAN software kernel and are only supported in Cisco SD-WAN software releases that include those kernel changes. eMMC 5.0 storage is supported in Cisco SD-WAN software releases 18.4.4 and later. Earlier releases do not support the new eMMC 5.0 based hardware.Cisco will begin to ship vEdge 100b and vEdge 100m routers with the eMMC 5.0 storage after supplies of the eMMC 4.5 components are exhausted. That changeover is expected to occur in June 2020. After the changeover, all new units will ship with eMMC 5.0 based storage and will include SD-WAN software (18.4.4 or later) that supports the new storage. eMMC 5.0 based routers cannot be downgraded to any SD-WAN software release prior to 18.4.4.
data.problemSymptoms: Cisco vEdge 100b and vEdge 100m routers with eMMC 5.0 storage require SD-WAN software release 18.4.4 or later. Earlier Cisco vEdge software versions will fail to boot. Note: Cisco vEdge software versions 18.3.0 through 18.3.8 will boot on eMMC 5.0 based routers, but the configuration is not supported and might produce unpredictable results.
data.workaround: Customers are strongly encouraged to upgrade their SD-WAN software installation to version 18.4.4 or later. eMMC 5.0 storage support is not possible in the older SD-WAN software releases prior to version 18.3.0. In addition, there are a number of software defects and security vulnerabilities in older releases that have been fixed in version 18.4.4 and later.Cisco has announced End of Sale, End of Life for SD-WAN software releases 18.3 and earlier.End-of-Sale and End-of-Life Announcement for the Cisco Viptela Software Release 18.3 and older versions
data.caveat: Manual verification of chassis hardware version and software release is required.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70567 - C9200/C9200L Devices That Run on Certain 16.12.x and 17.1.1/17.2.1 Cisco IOS XE Releases Will Exhibit MAC Address Update Failure - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: C9200L/C9200 Devices that run on IOS XE Releases as mentioned under the Products Affected Section will exhibit failure around Mac address update and port interface counter update.
data.background: The issue is caused due to internal software timer being impacted after a system uptime of 49 days 17 hrs.
data.problemSymptoms: The affected product will show the following known symptoms after 49 days 17hrs of uptime/operation:No new MAC address learningNo removal of MAC addresses after aging timeoutPort Interface counters not incrementingPacket drops to specific hosts in subnet
data.workaround: Reload the switch to  temporarily recover from this problem. However, this failure > The switch can be reloaded proactively to avoid this issue occurrence before the uptime reaches 49 days 17 hrs.  Cisco recommends upgrading to below releases or installing the Reload SMU on the existing software version which has fix for this issue. Current running SW versionFix available for SW releaseComment16.12.1 or 16.12.2 or 16.12.3Option 1: Upgrade to 16.12.3a or above Customers are encouraged to look for recommended release (marked as *) on CCO or refer to the  release recommendation page for the Catalyst Switching products.Option 2: Install SMU for the current SW version. SMU is available on CCO for the respective release.The switch will be reloaded after SMU is installed (C9200/C9200L supports only Reload SMU)17.1.1 or 17.2.1Option 1: Downgrade to 16.12.3a or above in 16.12 release train.Customers are encouraged to look for recommended release (marked as *) on CCO or refer to the  release recommendation page for the Catalyst Switching products.Option 2: Upgrade to 17.3.1 or above once it is available on CCO (tentative target date is 1st week of August 2020). Option 3: Engineering special image with the fix for IOS-XE 17.1 or 17.2 is available on request. Please contact Cisco TAC to assist you on this.Engineering Special builds are meant to be deployed for a limited time frame only and customers are advised to move to the release version with the fix as soon as it is available on cisco.com16.12.1s or !6.12.2tUpgrade to 16.12.3s once it is available on CCO (tentative target date for this is last week of May 2020). 17.1.1sUpgrade to 17.3.1 or above once it is available on CCO (tentative target date for this is 1st week of August 2020)>

data.bulletinTitle: FN70577 - Regulatory Compliance Issue with AP2800/AP3800/AP4800/AP1560/IW6300 - Software Upgrade Recommended
data.problemDescription: Access Points (APs) that have installed this software fail to comply with the Dynamic Frequency Selection (DFS) radar detection requirements during normal operation when the devices operate on DFS channels. This is Cisco bug ID CSCvt47413.Also, an AP that performs a mandatory Channel Availability Check (CAC) for a channel that requires the use of DFS fails to complete the CAC if the Transmit power is changed during the CAC. The AP initiates beaconing immediately. This is Cisco bug ID CSCvt98797.Customers who operate APs with this software might be operating in violation of regulatory requirements.
data.background: APs use radio spectrum that is regulated by governments, which includes regulators such as the US Federal Communications Commission, the European Commission, or individual national authorities. All APs must adhere to the technical conditions imposed by regulators with respect to radio emissions. One mandatory technical requirement is DFS, which requires that APs operate in portions of the 5 GHz band to listen for civil and military radars, and when radar patterns are detected, to stop transmissions and change channels to avoid co-channel operation with these radars. DFS protects these military and civilian radar systems, which includes safety-of-life systems, from harmful interference.Software updates made available between February and June 2020 have impacted the ability of the specific devices to properly detect these radar events. As a result, APs that use the specific software version as listed in this document are out of compliance with regulatory requirements. All customers, regardless of location, should take the action recommended in this field notice. U.S.-based customers should also review FCC Enforcement Advisory No. 2019-06.Specifically, these 5 (five) AP Series are affected: AP2800, AP3800, AP4800, AP1560, and IW6300.If you do not upgrade to the fixed software version, in some jurisdictions you might be exposed to legal liability. You will be exposed if and only if:You operate affected APs, andThe APs run affected code, andYour APs operate on DFS channels now or will in the future.
data.problemSymptoms: There is no customer visible symptom.
data.workaround: Solution Upgrade to a fixed software release based on the guidelines in this table.Affected VersionUpgrade to this VersionCommentsAireOS 8.5.161.1 through 8.5.161.3AireOS 8.5.161.4 or laterAireOS 8.5 MR6 Escalation, available from the Technical Assistance Center (TAC)AireOS 8.10.112.0AireOS 8.10.113.0 or later AireOS 8.10.112.1 through 8.10.112.9AireOS 8.10.121.5, 8.10.122.0 or laterAireOS 8.10.121.5 is available from the TACAireOS 8.10.121.0AireOS 8.10.122.0 or later AireOS 8.10.121.1 through 8.10.121.3AireOS 8.10.121.5 or laterAireOS 8.10 MR2 Escalation, available from theTACCisco IOS XE 17.1.1sCisco IOS XE 17.1.1tFor 9800 and EWC-APCisco IOS XE 17.1.1sCisco IOS XE 17.1.1s ESFor Embedded Wireless Controller on switchesCisco IOS XE 17.2.1Cisco IOS XE 17.2.1a  Immediate WorkaroundConfigure all vulnerable deployments not to use DFS channels until the software upgrade can be completed.In Radio Resource Management for 5GHz, edit the Dynamic Channel Assignment (DCA) list to remove the DFS channels, andConfigure any radios with static channel assignment to use non-DFS channels.For Cisco products, the DFS channels are in 5250 to 5350 MHz (channels 52-64) and in 5470 to 5725 MHz (channels 100-144).Note: This is intended to be a practical workaround in order to avoid the potential interference de>
data.caveat: Automation is not checking the AP models registered to the controller or whether DFS is in use.  Matching is only the Software Version of the Controller.

data.bulletinTitle: FN70594 - New APIC L3 or M3 Server Might Have Certificate Issue - Workaround Provided
data.problemDescription: A newly received Application Policy Infrastructure Controller (APIC) L3 or M3 server can be received with a certificate in which the subject is in an unexpected order.
data.background: An X.509 library function was changed in the mid-April timeframe which resulted in certificates generated with an unexpected subject format. The APIC is unable to extract validity information from the certificate due to this unexpected subject format.
data.problemSymptoms: A new APIC L3 or M3 server will not be able to complete fabric discovery. Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP), the acidiag verifyapic command, and other general checks will not exhibit a problem.The appliancedirector logs of an affected Cisco APIC should be checked for messages that indicate that the rejection happens due to being unable to parse the certificate subject.APIC# less /var/log/dme/log/svc_ifc_appliancedirector.bin.logcryptoERRORco=ifmFailed to parse subject from peer SSL certificate (/CN=ASD1234567/serialNumber=PID:APIC-SERVER-L3 SN:ASD1234567)../common/src/ifm/./PeerVerificationUtils.cc287cryptoERRORco=ifmPeer Certificate Subject is not in the expected format - REJECTING IFM SSL PEER CONNECTION../common/src/ifm/./PeerVerificationUtils.cc526
data.workaround: Contact the Technical Assistance Center (TAC) in order to generate and reprogram the APIC certificates.
